trial_identification.scientifictitle: A single group interventional trial of the effect of high flow oxygen on angina in patients with coronary disease

interventions.interventions: High flow oxygen (administered as 15L/min via a non-rebreather mask for 30 minutes)

primaryOutcome.outcome: First onset of definite angina replicating the subject's normal symptoms.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed during the 30 minutes the subject is receiving high flow oxygen.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: New ST segment changes greater than or equal to 1mm or T wave inversion as demonstrated by an electrocardiogram (ECG).
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed during the 30 minutes the subject is receiving high flow oxygen.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Need to stop the intervention because of any reason deemed to be of clinical concern by the attending doctor.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed during the 30 minutes the subject is receiving high flow oxygen.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Current inpatients on the cardiac care unit (CCU) Wellington Hospital; confirmed diagnosis of coronary disease on angiography; experiencing chest pain (at rest or with minimal exertion) considered by CCU staff to be consistent with angina.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Patients with chest pain at the time of enrolment; diagnosis of severe Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) or emphysema; room air oxygen saturations less than 92%; presence of bundle branch block pattern on resting ECG; patients requiring intravenous nitrates; glyceryl trinitrate use in the previous 2 hours.

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: Medical Research Institute of New Zealand

fundingsource.fundingname: Medical Research Institute of New Zealand

ethicsAndSummary.summary: It is routine clinical practice to administer high flow oxygen to patients with a heart attack or angina; however, there is some evidence to suggest that this approach may be harmful, especially in patients who are not hypoxic. This single group interventional trial aims to test this by recruiting 50 inpatients from the coronary care unit at Wellington Hospital who have confirmed coronary disease and a history of angina at rest or with minimal exertion. Subjects will receive high flow oxygen for 30 minutes. Subjects will be monitored to establish if angina occurs during the oxygen administration and if so how soon after it starts. ECGs will be taken throughout the study to monitor for any significant changes.
